_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

It is the policy of the Fogelsville Division to comply fully with all federal, state, and local rules and regulations regarding the proper handling, use, storage, and emergency response preparedness to prevent accidental release of chemicals toxic or otherwise.  Furthermore, Fogelsville Division is committed to protecting the health and welfare of both its employees and community residents.

Fogelsville Division makes all effort not to have an accidental release by having:
a.    Training and testing program
b.    Safety check sheets
c.    Equipment inspections

Our emergency response program is based upon the requirements in OSHA?s Hazardous Waste and Emergency Operations (HAZWOPER) regulation (29 CFR 1910.120).  For emergency response the company has in place:
a.    Contingency plan
b.    Evacuation plan
c.    Chemical spill procedures
d.    First aid and CPR training

2.    Stationary source and regulated substance handled

Carpenter Co., Fogelsville Division is located at 57A Olin Way and occupies 385,000 square feet.  Carpenter Co. is located in Fogelsville, PA, south of Route 78 and East of Route 100 and is surrounded by an industrial neighborhood.  The facility is located on 35 acres.

Carpenter Co. manufactures polyurethane foam products primarily for use in furniture, cushioning, bedding, undercarpet padding, and packaging.  The manufacturing process incorporates the use of Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI).  Inside the building, up to 375,000 pounds of TDI is stored in three steel storage tanks.  The tanks are located in a cement pit that can contain 62,000 gallons.  TDI is shipped primarily via railcar, which contains approximately 190,000 lbs.  The covered process is assigned a Program Level 1.

3.    Worst case scenario and alternative release scenario

Losing the entire contents of a TDI railcar (190,000 lbs) would be t

he worst case release.  If this happens the contents would be contained in a 15? x 90? diked area surrounding the rail tracks.  The diked area is large enough to contain a full railcar.  The endpoint distance is equal to 95 feet.  The nearest fence line is 171 feet away.  A worst case spill would remain onsite.  No alternative release scenario is required for the Program Level 1 covered process.

4.    General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

To prevent an accidental release, the following are implemented:
a.    Procedural
1.    Back-up chemical unloading
2.    Check-off lists
3.    Visual observation while unloading
b.    Training
1.    Hands on training and test
2.    VHS video training
3.    Unload training documentation

5.    Five-year accident history

During the last five years no TDI related incidents were recorded.

6.    Emergency response program

Carpenter Co. has a Contingency Plan.  The plan is a combination of a Preparedness, Prevention and Contingency (PPC) Plan and a Spill Prevention Response (SPR) Plan.  The plan is written to comply with all portions of our NPDES storm water permit (PAS232208) and RMP for toluene diisocyanate.  Telephone numbers of all agencies we expect to respond are in the Contingency Plan.  The following have received a copy of the Contingency Plan.
a.    Fogelsville Fire Department
b.    Upper Macungie Fire Marshall
c.    Lehigh County Emergency Management Agency
d.    The Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency
e.    Allentown Fire Department
Carpenter Co. has a coordination agreement with the Shaw Group (Nationwide Emergency Response) for environmental incidents we cannot handle.  Our in house Haz Mat Team members will be First Responder Operational certified.  Safety meetings are held monthly.  Evacuation drills are conducted annually.  We have employees trained in first aid and CPR.  The local Fire Department will be asked to handle public notification if it becomes necessary.
